body:
This is the same as the old pull request:
https://github.com/groovy/groovy-core/pull/431
CÃ©dric was concerned that the CompileStatic "part of the issue" wouldn't be correct. It is true that this change alters a missingMethod hook that is still generated even with CompileStatic in place but I checked and the code generated with CompileStatic looks good and doesn't use the methodMissing hooks (and appears to work fine). I'll assume that some other code change fixed the CompileStatic issue.
Works locally for me too. I'd punt on a sporadic error on the CI server and commit. Hopefully not famous last words! :-)
Lol.  I was looking for a button to re-kick Travis, but couldn't find it anywhere.
Thanks!

Change looks good to me.  Though I think it might be better to keep the `#newInstance(boolean)` and create a new no-args newInstance that it could delegate to just in case anyone is currently using the method.  That way it wouldn't be a breaking change (even though the `org.codehaus.groovy` package is considered somewhat internal) and would be easier to incorporate into the 2_4_X branch also.
@jwagenleitner Fair enough!  I have restored the old method, and added comments to document the backward compatibility bit.  Thanks!
I would probably deprecate the old method too

@tychobrailleur Thanks for the PR!

I went ahead and added the deprecated tags as Paul suggested.
I'm not a groovy-json user, but this looks good as far as I can tell. :+1:
Merged (with license header as per John's comment). Thanks!
Merged, thanks!
PR merged.
+1, looks okay to me but I'm not super familiar with how performance might be affected at this level
Will this work with `@CompileStatic`? I noticed the use of static method missing

This PR in its current form doesn't address any issues with @CompileStatic access for methods in outer classes - this is just handling the dynamic code cases. It shouldn't impact @CS classes but also won't fix any bugs with @CompileStatic for these scenarios. It would certainly be good to have the equivalent scenarios examined for @TC and @CS.

Since there is already a DGM method `T last(List<T>)` that does what `popLast()` does and `List#add(T)` appends just like `pushLast(T)`, maybe if those were mentioned in the javadoc for `push/pop` as alternatives to use if location of the items is important the new methods wouldn't be needed?

Thanks for looking it over, I appreciate it.

I'll let it sit for a while and see if I can get some time to do a quick benchmark.  Not sure how often `floats/doubles` are used in tight loops and compared using the Groovy Truth, but probably wouldn't hurt to make sure it's not too costly of an extra check for `NaN`.
Nevermind my last comment about `last`, I should have noticed the get vs remove.

You are correct about `pushLast` vs `add` but since this is a breaking change I was thinking having the `pushLast` alias will make it easier to explain to people. If you want the old behavior, use xxxLast. It also aligns with the naming scheme for Deque, e.g. peekFirst, peekLast, etc. But if there is a general consensus that the extra alias isn't needed, I am happy to remove it.

I definitely agree that it would be good to have some replacement for removing the last element from the list (the reverse of `add`).  My guess it that that is a use case for using `pop` today (I know I have code that does that).  One alternative may be to add a `removeLast()` in place of `popLast()` and leave out `pushLast` in favor or `add`.  Just a thought, but think the `xxxxLast` methods are ok.
Changed as per John's suggestions.
+1 (see inline comment)

Thanks for the PR.  Would you mind creating a JIRA ticket for this change (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY)?  It helps to have a issue filed since they help to build a changelog for releases.  Also, if you're up for it, the same problem exists in `ObjectRange` if you want to make the same fix there.
+1, nice catch.

John, I incorporated your changes but tried to not explicitly reference `Deque`. `Deque`/`LinkedList` is obviously the class we are trying to align behavior with and it lets you `push`/`pop` off the head (start) or end (via `add`/`removeLast`) but I was trying to explain the behavior without the complication of necessarily wanting to have to consider having both capabilities. Let me know what you think.
Proposed PR merged.
I think the docs do a good job of describing the behavior and agree that it's best to not mention specific interface/impl.  Everything looks good to me.
I'll close this PR and open a new one. If `$static_propertyMissing` is plumbed in correctly, the need to have the extra outer levels goes away since it will propagate outwards. See PR#425.
+1. I would think that this is worth doing in the meantime anyway. If we get a Gradle fix later, we can always remove the field.
as step in between, yes +1
PR merged, thanks!
Proposed PR merged.
It is still seen in 2.4.7
Thank you!

Actually, wrt my last comment, perhaps this issue is a good place to track those differences:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7850

Thanks for reporting. Sadly I myself have little occasion to use groovysh.

I confirm the following still does not work:

```
groovy:000> :set interpreterMode true
groovy:000> import java.rmi.Remote
java.rmi.Remote
===> java.rmi.Remote
groovy:000> Remote r
DEBUG [org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.InteractiveShellRunner] Read line: Remote r
DEBUG [org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.RigidParser] Parsing: import java.rmi.Remote;
Remote r
DEBUG [org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.RigidParser] Parse complete
DEBUG [org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.Groovysh] Evaluating buffer...
ERROR org.codehaus.groovy.control.MultipleCompilationErrorsException:
script1474514709372448239816.groovy: 1: unable to resolve class Remote 
 @ line 1, column 8.
   Remote r
          ^
```

However, the cause remains unclear, the create buffer for evaluation seems correct and complete:

```
DEBUG [org.codehaus.groovy.tools.shell.RigidParser] Parsing: import java.rmi.Remote;
Remote r
```

And a unit test should have caught this problem...
Ah, well, the fixing commits are on the master branch, but not in 2.4.7. So nothing I can do. @PascalSchumacher
Continued in https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/38
+1 these changes would be awesome, and if we can include https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-6975 even better ;-)
I made the commit with wrong name, and I will open a PR again.
Any chance this can be merged? Thanks...
Actually hold off merging, found an a potential issue and will revise the test case and update the pull request
Revised pull request, since it created issues handling `GString` instances which are also `Writable`
The failures on Travis seem to be unrelated network issues?
PR merged, thanks!  Travis doesn't seem to always like building against the 2_4_X branch, seems to fail spuriously.  Hope you don't mind but I squashed the commits.
This seems related to https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/371
@jwagenleitner Sweet! #433 seems another candidate to combine with this change. Thoughts?
should we limit the lookup of is-property-accessor-methods to boolean returning ones?

Agreed, the lookups should match groovy's generation of synthetic methods.
On Tue, Oct 4, 2016 at 5:44 PM Jochen Theodorou notifications@github.com
wrote:

> should we limit the lookup of is-property-accessor-methods to boolean
> returning ones?

+1 with the check for boolean

What are the plans for this now that #219 is merged? There should be much less of an issue, but it would still be nice to be able to eagerly evict classes from the cache when they are not used anymore instead of waiting for the GC to kick in.
Amended to reflect @blackdrag 's comment
I created [GROOVY-7960](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7960) for this and will merge this PR soon unless there are objections.

I am thinking of going ahead and adding the new `ClassInfo#remove` method and adding the call to it in the `InvokerHelper#removeClass` method.   Those seem like reasonable changes that would not cause any issues and provides the programmer a way to clean up if they choose assuming they have a reference to the Script class.

I am less sure about the clean up done in GroovyShell itself.  In rethinking this, I definitely think the `Eval` class can do some automated cleanup after execution but am not comfortable with doing it in GroovyShell.  So part two after the changes mentioned above would be to see about redoing this PR for `Eval` (as reported in the issue) and not `GroovyShell`.

It might be nice to have a method on `GroovyClassLoader`, `GroovyShell` and `GroovyScriptEngine` (such as `flushCaches` or maybe even make it `Closeable`) so that (more aggressive) cleanup could be initiated if desired but not automatically since they may cause unforeseen issues.

Would be curious to know everyone's thoughts.

Hi,
I might be able to get around to making some more changes tonight, but for now I think it may be best to merge this and the other one can come in another PR. I went ahead and made a sister ticket at:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-7962
Ok.  I had opened GROOVY-7961 for ObjectRange when I opened the one for IntRange, so 7962 is a duplicate.

ClassInfo#remove is fine, adding it to InvokerHelper#removeClass is probably fine too. Doing this to Eval is probably working out, since you rarely will create a class within the eval and then using meta programming on it. For the other three this is different, but adding a flushCaches we could have. Of course if we use Closeable, we could use close instead. Adding this to GroovyShell and GroovyScriptEngine would be actually a good idea I think. GroovyClassLoader is, because it is extending URLClassloader, already closeable... so it could go there even without adding a new interface.
This change is probably to be considered as a breaking change. If John is ok with this I am ok with having this on master for 2.5.0
I think we can merge that

+1 (I changed the issue to have a breaking label - this is slightly pedantic as it is an undesirable edge case that will break but it should make it easier to find if anyone is relying on that edge case - see my comments on the issue for further details)

Maybe we should split this into smaller chunks. I think we all agree about `ClassInfo#remove` and adding it to `InvokerHelper#removeClass`, so that could be one PR.
Using `flushCaches/close` in `GroovyShell`, `GroovyScriptEngine`, and `GroovyClassLoader` seems reasonable to me too. The latter would just do a `classCache.values().forEach(InvokerHelper::removeClass)`, right?
`GroovyShell` and `GroovyScriptEngine` would probably just have to `close()` their `GroovyClassLoader` from their `close()` methods then, but since they are both extensible public API, adding the `Closeable` interface would probably have to wait for 3.x.
Those licenses should be generated into the root directory (well actually licenses) not src/spec/assets. You should exclude them from your PR.
Ok, I've excluded the licenses.

All,
The matching PR is here:
https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/440
PR merged, thanks!
PR merged, thanks!

+1, looks great - some minor comments added inline - I think extensibility does need to be considered as per Graeme's comments but if you think that is going to cause further delay, we can always do that as a separate PR/commit

Thanks for the PR.

I haven't gone through it in detail, but wonder if we didn't use the diamond operator on `cachedImports` and retained the method signature of `collectImportedSymbols` if this fix would be eligible for 2_4_X?

I could get rid of the diamond operator and preserve the method signatures,
and incorporate whatever other feedback if it helps get the fix released
sooner.

wrote:

BTW: I'm aware that commits must be rebased before merging them to the main branch (All have WIP...). I'm keeping them to keep track of the suggestions.
+1, looks good to me, I'll merge in a day or two if no-one spots any issues

I added a bunch of mostly cosmetic suggestions. Looks really great overall. I also get the same test failures even though they seem unrelated at first glance. I'll look into that when I get the chance.

@paulk-asert so far, the only issue I see is the order change. It potentially might happen if we change the visitors, but I have no idea how to force the order. Is it safe to rely on the order of visit right now? Is it depth-first search?
Proposed PR merged.
I created PRs #444 and #445, I hope we can get these in for 2.4.7.
Any problem prevents the PR from merging?

I was just going to play a little more with ordering ...

On Tue, Oct 11, 2016 at 10:04 PM, Daniel.Sun notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Any problem prevents the PR from merging?
> 
> â

> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AARF0Ie9GRUvVyjqumVRnjp3L9jUexDyks5qy3tJgaJpZM4KRxYf
> .
Thanks!  I merged this in master and 2_4_X so it should be in 2.4.8 when released.
Thanks!  I only merged this into master (2.5.0) since `URLClassLoader` implements `Closeable` as of Java 7.  The 2.4.x branch still supports Java 6.
@jochenberger thanks for the PRs, both merged.  The `ClassInfo#remove` should get in 2.4.8 but the `GroovyClassLoader#close` will be in 2.5.0 since 2.4.8 still has Java 6 as supported.

Thanks for the test case @paulk-asert, that was helpful.  I added the `ClassCodeExpressionTransformer` transformer so that the test would break in 2_4_X (without relying on the macro transform being in place) since this fix seems like something that could go in that branch as well as master, but would be interested to know what you think.
Nice. +1 for both branches.

I forgot to mention that while the changes to the test (removing `import`) seems to be a significant change, I think this was a problem with the tests not matching the actual behavior of Groovysh since it stores imports without the `import` as mentioned by the added comment.

In addition to fixing completion of static imports, I also found this fixes the completion of star imports.  Prior to this fix `import java.text.*` and typing `new SimpleDa<tab>` would not return `SimpleDateFormat`, after this fix it does.
Merged
